questions.stem: West Nile virus is a member of which virus family?
questions.explanation: West Nile virus is a member of the family Flaviviridae, from the genus Orthoflavivirus. Retroviridae (A), Herpesviridae (C), and Paramyxoviridae (D) are not correct.

questions.stem: West Nile virus is primarily transmitted by:
questions.explanation: West Nile virus is primarily transmitted by mosquitoes, mostly species of Culex. Ticks (A), direct contact (C), and contaminated feed (D) are not the primary transmission routes.

questions.stem: West Nile virus was first isolated in:

options.label: A
options.text: The Nile River region of Egypt

options.label: B
options.text: The West Nile district of Uganda

questions.explanation: West Nile virus was first isolated in the West Nile district of Uganda. It was not named directly after the Nile River (A), West Africa (C), or the Middle East (D).

questions.stem: West Nile virus causes:

options.label: B
options.text: Encephalomyelitis (inflammation of the brain and/or spinal cord)

questions.explanation: West Nile virus causes encephalomyelitis, which is inflammation of the brain and/or spinal cord, characterized by central nervous system dysfunction. Respiratory disease (A), gastrointestinal disease (C), and skin lesions (D) are not the primary manifestations.

questions.stem: The morbidity rate for West Nile virus in horses is approximately:
questions.explanation: The morbidity rate for West Nile virus in horses is approximately 10%. Lower rates (A, B) or higher rates (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: The mortality rate for West Nile virus in horses is approximately:
questions.explanation: The mortality rate for West Nile virus in horses is approximately 50%. Lower rates (A, B) or higher rates (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Which horses are MOST susceptible to severe West Nile virus disease?
questions.explanation: Older horses and unvaccinated horses develop more severe disease. Young foals (A), pregnant mares (C), or equal susceptibility (D) are not the most susceptible groups.

questions.stem: Early clinical signs of West Nile virus may include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Profuse diarrhea is not a typical early sign of West Nile virus. Discomfort or anxiety (A), lameness (B), and low-grade fever or malaise (C) are early signs.

questions.stem: Neurologic signs of West Nile virus include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.label: C
options.text: Inability to swallow and irregular gait

questions.explanation: While convulsions can occur, seizures are not listed among the typical neurologic signs. Muzzle twitching and impaired vision (A), aimless wandering and head pressing (B), and inability to swallow and irregular gait (C) are typical neurologic signs.

questions.stem: The gold standard diagnostic test for West Nile virus is:

options.label: C
options.text: Detection of IgM antibody by ELISA or PCR from tissue

questions.explanation: Diagnosis is made through detection of IgM antibody by ELISA or PCR from tissue. CBC (A) and IgG serology (B) are not the gold standard, and radiography (D) is not diagnostic.

questions.stem: Treatment for West Nile virus primarily consists of:

options.label: B
options.text: Supportive care, anti-inflammatory and pain medications

questions.explanation: Treatment primarily consists of supportive care, anti-inflammatory and pain medications. Antivirals (A), corticosteroids (C), and antibiotics (D) are not the primary treatment approach.

questions.stem: Serum and plasma products containing antibodies for West Nile virus:
questions.explanation: Serum and plasma products containing antibodies have no evidence of effectiveness. They are not highly effective (A), the treatment of choice (C), or contraindicated (D).

questions.stem: Most horses that recover from West Nile virus return to normal functioning within:
questions.explanation: Most horses that recover from West Nile virus return to normal functioning within 1 to 6 months. Shorter (A) or longer periods (C, D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Prevention of West Nile virus includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: Turning horses in at dusk and dawn when mosquitoes are most active

options.label: C
options.text: Keeping farms free of water-holding containers

questions.explanation: Administering prophylactic antibiotics is not a prevention measure for West Nile virus. Vaccination (A), turning horses in at dusk and dawn (B), and eliminating breeding sites (C) are prevention measures.

questions.stem: Mosquitoes are most actively feeding during:
questions.explanation: Mosquitoes are most actively feeding during dusk and dawn. Midday (A), midnight (C), or all times equally (D) are not when mosquitoes are most active.

questions.stem: Water-holding containers that can serve as mosquito breeding sites include:

options.label: A
options.text: Old tires, barrels, buckets, tubs, and wheelbarrows

questions.explanation: Water-holding containers that can serve as mosquito breeding sites include old tires, barrels, buckets, tubs, and wheelbarrows. Only natural ponds (B), only artificial containers (C), or none (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: In humans, West Nile virus infection is asymptomatic in approximately:
questions.explanation: In humans, West Nile virus infection is asymptomatic in approximately 80% of cases. Lower percentages (A, B) or 100% (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Neurological disease develops in less than what percentage of human West Nile virus infections?
questions.explanation: Neurological disease develops in less than 1% of human West Nile virus infections. Lower (A) or higher percentages (C, D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Case fatality in humans with neurological West Nile virus disease may be as high as:
questions.explanation: Case fatality in humans with neurological West Nile virus disease may be as high as 20%. Lower rates (A, B) or higher rates (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: West Nile virus has been called "Near Eastern equine encephalitis" or "lordige" in:
questions.explanation: West Nile virus has been called "Near Eastern equine encephalitis" or "lordige" in France. Uganda (A), Egypt (C), and the United States (D) are not where these names were used.
